awd_titl_txt: The roles of exaptive and adaptive co-option in eye evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
A basic question in biology asks: Where do new complex traits, such as eyes, come from, and in particular, where do the genes that encode them come from? Despite the many different eye types possessed by animals from jellyfish to humans, the genes affecting how light is transformed into the chemical signals of seeing are similar across eyes.  Interestingly, some of these genes necessary for light-sensing in eyes are also found in organs not used for vision. Therefore, it may be that the light-sensing machinery used in eyes came from a non-eye origin. This project looks at how genes can be turned on and off in a new place in the body or at different times during development to generate eyes. In doing so it will help us more generally to understand how organisms can evolve to repurpose their genes to create entirely new organs. The work will produce new genome sequences that can be used by commercial and governmental agencies in aquaculture development for economically important species, like scallops, oysters, and clams.  It will also improve 7-12th grade educators' understanding of evolution to help them achieve the Next Generation Science Standards goals. This will be done by training them to better teach molecular evolution, and creating and disseminating novel lesson plans for teaching molecular evolution to high school students. The research will also provide training opportunities in cutting edge fields of genomics and bioinformatics to postdoctoral researchers and undergraduate students. This will increase the skills of the next generation of workers in using DNA-based tools and analyses. 
 
Understanding the evolutionary origin of eyes is of great interest to biologists because eyes provide insight into how complex phenotypes can arise through redeployment and elaboration of genetic pathways. Yet, previous studies have not utilized closely related taxa that possess a diversity of eye types. This work will examine five separate origins of eyes in a group of closely related bivalves in the Pteriomorphia. Using a combination of tissue-specific transcriptomes and genome assembly, the researchers will identify genes involved in phototransduction across species spanning the taxonomic and ocular diversity of the Pteriomorphia and analyze these in a phylogenetic framework to understand how changes to either the location or timing of gene expression has played a role in the evolution of pteriomorphian eye type diversity. The work will address the following questions: 1) Are lineages with eyes associated with gene family expansions of the phototransduction pathway members? 2) What is the degree of similarity of the phototransduction genes between the different photoreceptive structures within and among species? and 3) Do eyes acquire their phototransduction pathways using the same evolutionary process or does each eye have a unique evolutionary trajectory to photoreception? This work is the first phylogenetic investigation of eye evolution in bivalves, and builds on the PIs' research, recently available genomic resources, and new data on phototransduction pathway evolution. The project will thus advance knowledge of how sensory systems evolve.

por.por_cntn:
Eyes have evolved independently numerous times in animals and encompass a great diversity of form. Surprisingly, the core molecular components responsible for detecting light—such as opsins, the proteins that respond to light—are remarkably conserved across species. A growing body of research suggests, rather than evolving de novo, eyes may have emerged through a process known as "co-option," where genes that originally served other purposes were repurposed for vision. Understanding the origin of eyes will provide insight into how complex structures can arise through redeployment and elaboration of genetic pathways and whether genetic complexity is needed to generate morphological complexity.

Our research examined co-option of opsin by first studying the gene family across 80 species of mollusks, a group that includes clams, oysters, snails, and squids. These animals possess a variety of eye types, from simple eyespots to optically complex camera-like eyes. We discovered that the number of opsin genes present in genome varies significantly among species, from none in species living in dark environments, to as many as 66 opsin genes in the eyeless zebra mussel. This finding challenges the assumption that the presence of eyes directly correlates with the number of opsin genes, suggesting that opsins may have other functions beyond vision.

To explore these additional roles, we examined whether opsin genes were turned on (expressed) when eyes were not present. We focused on eyeless bivalve larvae, which undergo metamorphosis, a critical transition from free-swimming forms to stationary adults. Light is known to influence this process, so we investigated whether opsins might play a role. We found that opsins are indeed active in the larval stages, with some opsins expressed in much higher levels in larvae than in adult light-sensitive tissues. Furthermore, opsin expression increased as larvae approached metamorphosis, when they develop temporary eyespots and become ready transform into their adult forms. This finding strongly suggests that bivalve larvae use opsins to detect light during this crucial phase of their life cycle. However, the presence of multiple opsin genes in these species raises an intriguing question: why do some species have so many opsins if only one is needed to detect light?

Our research suggests that bivalve opsins may be used to detect more than just light. The variation in opsin gene expression across different species, even those that are closely related, indicates that these proteins may also respond to other environmental factors such as chemicals or temperature. This broader sensory role for opsins is consistent with findings in insects and mice, where opsins can also sense chemical and thermal cues. In bivalves, we observed that many opsin genes had higher expression as larvae approached the point of settling, when they need to detect environmental signals that help them decide where to anchor themselves for the rest of their lives.

These discoveries suggest that opsins play a much more versatile role in mollusk biology than previously thought. Instead of being confined to vision, opsins may help bivalve larvae detect a wide array of environmental cues, including light, chemicals, or temperature. This finding underscores the idea that complex traits like vision can evolve by reusing existing genetic pathways for new purposes, rather than by creating entirely new genes or systems.

Our study also has implications for bivalve aquaculture, which accounts for 89% of global production. Despite being a critical source of animal protein for more than 1.5 billion people worldwide, aquaculture can be challenging, especially during the larval stage. Survival during metamorphosis depends on precise environmental conditions and inadequate cues for settlement can lead to high mortality rates. Understanding how larvae detect these cues is essential for improving bivalve aquaculture. Our research suggests that opsins, which are active in larvae during metamorphosis, may play a key role in detecting the environmental signals that guide this process.

Beyond the scientific findings, the project made a lasting societal impact by advancing STEM education. The lab created authentic research experiences for four high school teachers (RETs). Each of our teacher-interns gained firsthand experience with the scientific method, from experiment design to data analysis and interpretation. Lab members assisted teachers in translating their research experiences into classroom curriculum aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards. In turn, lab members learned how to explain their research and evolutionary theory to a lay audience, key skills to promote scientific literacy and write successful grant applications. Teachers returned to their classrooms with deeper content knowledge and renewed excitement for science. The return on NSF’s investment is extremely high. Given that a typical high school teacher has 150 students in an academic year, the impact of these teachers extends to thousands of students over the course of their career.
